Up Youthes and Virgins, up, and praise</br>The God, whose Nights out-shine his daies;</br>HYMEN, whose hallowed rites</br>Could never boast of brighter lights:</br>Whose bands passe libertee.</br>Two of your troope, that, with the morne were free,</br>Are, now, wag'd to his warre.</br>And what they are,</br>If you'll perfection see,</br>Your selves must be.</br>Shine, HESPERUS, shine forth, thou wished Starre.

What Joy, or honors can compare</br>With holy Nuptialls, when they are</br>Made out of aequall parts</br>Of yeares, of states, of hands, of hearts?</br>When, in the happy choyce,</br>The Spouse, and Spoused have the formost voyce!</br>Such, glad of HYMENS warre,</br>Live what they are,</br>And long perfection see:</br>And such ours bee.</br>Shine, Hesperus, shine forth, thou wished Starre.

The solemne state of this one Night</br>Were fit to last an Ages light;</br>But there are rites behind</br>Have lesse of state, but more of kind:</br>Loves wealthy croppe of kisses,</br>And fruitfull harvest of his Mothers blisses.</br>Sound then to HYMENS warre:</br>That what these are,</br>Who will perfection see,</br>May haste to bee.</br>Shine, Hesperus, shine forth, thou wished Starre.

Loves common wealth consists of toyes;</br>His councell are those antique boyes,</br>Games, Laughters, Sports, Delights,</br>That triumphe with him on these nightes:</br>To whome we must give way,</br>For now their raigne beginnes, and lasts till day.</br>They sweeten HYMENS warre,</br>And, in that jarre,</br>Make all, that married bee,</br>Perfection see.</br>Shine, Hesperus, shine forth, thou wished Starre.

Why stayes the Bride-groome to invade</br>Her, that would be a Matron made?</br>Good-night, whilst yet we may</br>Good-night, to you a Virgin, say:</br>To morrow, rise the same</br>Your Mother is, and use a nobler name.</br>Speed well in HYMEN'S warre,</br>That, what you are,</br>By your perfection, wee</br>And all may see.</br>Shine, Hesperus, shine forth, thou wished Starre.

To night is VENUS vigil kept.</br>This night no Bridegroome ever slept;</br>And if the fayre Bride doo,</br>The married say, 'tis his fault, too.</br>Wake then; and let your lightes</br>Wake too:  for they'l tell nothing of your nightes:</br>But, that in HYMENS warre,</br>You perfect are.</br>And such perfection, wee</br>Doe pray, should be.</br>Shine, Hesperus, shine forth, thou wished Starre.

That, ere the rosy-fingerd Morne</br>Behold nine moones, there may be borne</br>A Babe, t' uphold the fame</br>Of Radcliffes blood, and Ramsey's name:</br>That may, in his great seed,</br>Weare the long honors of his Fathers deed.</br>Such fruicts of Hymens warre</br>Most perfect are;</br>And all perfection, wee</br>Wish, you should see.</br>Shine, Hesperus, shine forth, thou wished Starre.</br>
